natural problem: When the vectors $\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$
natural solution: Note that the vector $\mathbf{p}$ must lie on the line passing through $\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5t + 4 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]

usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); pair A, B, O, P; A = (4,1); B = (-1,3); O = (0,0); P = (O + reflect(A,B)*(O))/2; draw((-2,0)--(5,0)); draw((0,-1)--(0,4)); draw(O--A,Arrow(6)); draw(O--B,Arrow(6));

draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(interp(A,B,-0.1)--interp(A,B,1.1),dashed); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$", A, N); label("$\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$", B, N); label("$\mathbf{p}$", P, N);

[/asy] The vector $\mathbf{p}$ itself will be orthogonal to the direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix},$ so \[\begin{pmatrix} -5t + 4 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(-5t + 4)(-5) + (2t + 1)(2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{18}{29}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 26/29 \\ 65/29 \end{pmatrix}}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v p :: "real*real"
and v1 :: "real*real" and v2 :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "v1 = (4, 1)"
and h1 : "v2 = (-1, 3)"
and h2 : "\<forall>v. proj v v1 = p"
and h3 : "\<forall>v. proj v v2 = p"
shows  "p = (26/29, 65/29)" 

(Note: Here "proj" represents the projection operation for vectors.)
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the vectors $\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 26/29 \\ 65/29 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Note that the vector $\mathbf{p}$ must lie on the line passing through $\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5t + 4 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); pair A, B, O, P; A = (4,1); B = (-1,3); O = (0,0); P = (O + reflect(A,B)*(O))/2; draw((-2,0)--(5,0)); draw((0,-1)--(0,4)); draw(O--A,Arrow(6)); draw(O--B,Arrow(6));
 draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(interp(A,B,-0.1)--interp(A,B,1.1),dashed); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$", A, N); label("$\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$", B, N); label("$\mathbf{p}$", P, N);
 [/asy] The vector $\mathbf{p}$ itself will be orthogonal to the direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix},$ so \[\begin{pmatrix} -5t + 4 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(-5t + 4)(-5) + (2t + 1)(2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{18}{29}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 26/29 \\ 65/29 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes v p :: "real*real"
and v1 :: "real*real" and v2 :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "v1 = (4, 1)"
and h1 : "v2 = (-1, 3)"
and h2 : "\<forall>v. proj v v1 = p"
and h3 : "\<forall>v. proj v v2 = p"
shows  "p = (26/29, 65/29)" 

(Note: Here "proj" represents the projection operation for vectors.)
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the vector projection of any vector $v$ onto two given vectors $v1 = (4, 1)$ and $v2 = (-1, 3)$. The vector projection is the same point $p$ for both $v1$ and $v2$. Find the coordinates of point $p$. The final answer is $p = \left(\frac{26}{29}, \frac{65}{29}\right)$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v p :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "v = (4, 1)"
and h1 : "v = (-1, 3)"
and h2 : "p = proj v p"
shows  "p = (26 / 29, 65 / 29)"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the vectors $\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 26/29 \\ 65/29 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Note that the vector $\mathbf{p}$ must lie on the line passing through $\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5t + 4 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); pair A, B, O, P; A = (4,1); B = (-1,3); O = (0,0); P = (O + reflect(A,B)*(O))/2; draw((-2,0)--(5,0)); draw((0,-1)--(0,4)); draw(O--A,Arrow(6)); draw(O--B,Arrow(6));
 draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(interp(A,B,-0.1)--interp(A,B,1.1),dashed); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$", A, N); label("$\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$", B, N); label("$\mathbf{p}$", P, N);
 [/asy] The vector $\mathbf{p}$ itself will be orthogonal to the direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix},$ so \[\begin{pmatrix} -5t + 4 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(-5t + 4)(-5) + (2t + 1)(2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{18}{29}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 26/29 \\ 65/29 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes v p :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "v = (4, 1)"
and h1 : "v = (-1, 3)"
and h2 : "p = proj v p"
shows  "p = (26 / 29, 65 / 29)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given two vectors v = (4, 1) and v = (-1, 3), find the projection p of v onto p. The final answer is p = (26/29, 65/29).

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v p :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "v = (4,1)"
and h1 : "v = (-1,3)"
and h2 : "p = (26/29, 65/29)"
shows  "\<forall>w. w = v \<longrightarrow> project w v = p"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the vectors $\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 26/29 \\ 65/29 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Note that the vector $\mathbf{p}$ must lie on the line passing through $\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5t + 4 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); pair A, B, O, P; A = (4,1); B = (-1,3); O = (0,0); P = (O + reflect(A,B)*(O))/2; draw((-2,0)--(5,0)); draw((0,-1)--(0,4)); draw(O--A,Arrow(6)); draw(O--B,Arrow(6));
 draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(interp(A,B,-0.1)--interp(A,B,1.1),dashed); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$", A, N); label("$\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$", B, N); label("$\mathbf{p}$", P, N);
 [/asy] The vector $\mathbf{p}$ itself will be orthogonal to the direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix},$ so \[\begin{pmatrix} -5t + 4 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(-5t + 4)(-5) + (2t + 1)(2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{18}{29}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 26/29 \\ 65/29 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes v p :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "v = (4,1)"
and h1 : "v = (-1,3)"
and h2 : "p = (26/29, 65/29)"
shows  "\<forall>w. w = v \<longrightarrow> project w v = p"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given vectors v = (4,1) and w = (-1,3), find a point p such that the projection of w onto v equals p. The final answer is p = (26/29, 65/29).

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v p :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. v x y = (4 * x + y) / (x * x + y * y)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. p x y = (26/29 * x + 65/29 * y) / (x * x + y * y)"
and h2 : "v 4 1 = p 4 1"
and h3 : "v (-1) 3 = p (-1) 3"
shows  "\<forall> x y. v x y = p x y"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the vectors $\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 26/29 \\ 65/29 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Note that the vector $\mathbf{p}$ must lie on the line passing through $\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5t + 4 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); pair A, B, O, P; A = (4,1); B = (-1,3); O = (0,0); P = (O + reflect(A,B)*(O))/2; draw((-2,0)--(5,0)); draw((0,-1)--(0,4)); draw(O--A,Arrow(6)); draw(O--B,Arrow(6));
 draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(interp(A,B,-0.1)--interp(A,B,1.1),dashed); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$", A, N); label("$\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$", B, N); label("$\mathbf{p}$", P, N);
 [/asy] The vector $\mathbf{p}$ itself will be orthogonal to the direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix},$ so \[\begin{pmatrix} -5t + 4 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(-5t + 4)(-5) + (2t + 1)(2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{18}{29}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 26/29 \\ 65/29 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes v p :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. v x y = (4 * x + y) / (x * x + y * y)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. p x y = (26/29 * x + 65/29 * y) / (x * x + y * y)"
and h2 : "v 4 1 = p 4 1"
and h3 : "v (-1) 3 = p (-1) 3"
shows  "\<forall> x y. v x y = p x y"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Given two functions $v(x, y) = \frac{4x + y}{x^2 + y^2}$ and $p(x, y) = \frac{\frac{26}{29}x + \frac{65}{29}y}{x^2 + y^2}$. If we know that $v(4, 1) = p(4, 1)$ and $v(-1, 3) = p(-1, 3)$, then prove that $v(x, y) = p(x, y)$ for all real numbers $x$ and $y$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v p :: "real^2"
assumes h0 : "v = vector [4,1]"
and h1 : "v = vector [-1,3]"
and h2 : "p = (v dot v / (v dot v)) *s v"
shows  "p = vector [26/29, 65/29]"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the vectors $\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 26/29 \\ 65/29 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Note that the vector $\mathbf{p}$ must lie on the line passing through $\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5t + 4 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); pair A, B, O, P; A = (4,1); B = (-1,3); O = (0,0); P = (O + reflect(A,B)*(O))/2; draw((-2,0)--(5,0)); draw((0,-1)--(0,4)); draw(O--A,Arrow(6)); draw(O--B,Arrow(6));
 draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(interp(A,B,-0.1)--interp(A,B,1.1),dashed); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$", A, N); label("$\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$", B, N); label("$\mathbf{p}$", P, N);
 [/asy] The vector $\mathbf{p}$ itself will be orthogonal to the direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix},$ so \[\begin{pmatrix} -5t + 4 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(-5t + 4)(-5) + (2t + 1)(2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{18}{29}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 26/29 \\ 65/29 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes v p :: "real^2"
assumes h0 : "v = vector [4,1]"
and h1 : "v = vector [-1,3]"
and h2 : "p = (v dot v / (v dot v)) *s v"
shows  "p = vector [26/29, 65/29]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given that vectors $v$ and $u$ are defined as $v=[4,1]$ and $u=[-1,3]$ respectively, compute the projection of $v$ onto $u$ (denoted as $p$). The final answer is $p=[\frac{26}{29}, \frac{65}{29}]$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v p :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "\<exists> k. k * v = (4, 1)"
and h1 : "\<exists> k. k * v = (-1, 3)"
shows  "p = (26 / 29, 65 / 29)"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the vectors $\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 26/29 \\ 65/29 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Note that the vector $\mathbf{p}$ must lie on the line passing through $\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5t + 4 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); pair A, B, O, P; A = (4,1); B = (-1,3); O = (0,0); P = (O + reflect(A,B)*(O))/2; draw((-2,0)--(5,0)); draw((0,-1)--(0,4)); draw(O--A,Arrow(6)); draw(O--B,Arrow(6));
 draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(interp(A,B,-0.1)--interp(A,B,1.1),dashed); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$", A, N); label("$\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$", B, N); label("$\mathbf{p}$", P, N);
 [/asy] The vector $\mathbf{p}$ itself will be orthogonal to the direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix},$ so \[\begin{pmatrix} -5t + 4 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(-5t + 4)(-5) + (2t + 1)(2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{18}{29}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 26/29 \\ 65/29 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes v p :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "\<exists> k. k * v = (4, 1)"
and h1 : "\<exists> k. k * v = (-1, 3)"
shows  "p = (26 / 29, 65 / 29)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given vectors v, p in a two-dimensional space, find the vector v such that there exists a scalar k satisfying k*v = (4,1) and another scalar k satisfying k*v = (-1,3). The final answer is p = (26 / 29, 65 / 29).

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v p :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "v = (26/29, 65/29)"
and h1 : "\<forall> u. (u = (4, 1) \<or> u = (-1, 3)) \<longrightarrow> p = (fst u * fst v + snd u * snd v) / (fst v * fst v + snd v * snd v) *\<^sub>R v"
shows  "p = (26/29, 65/29)"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the vectors $\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 26/29 \\ 65/29 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Note that the vector $\mathbf{p}$ must lie on the line passing through $\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5t + 4 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); pair A, B, O, P; A = (4,1); B = (-1,3); O = (0,0); P = (O + reflect(A,B)*(O))/2; draw((-2,0)--(5,0)); draw((0,-1)--(0,4)); draw(O--A,Arrow(6)); draw(O--B,Arrow(6));
 draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(interp(A,B,-0.1)--interp(A,B,1.1),dashed); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$", A, N); label("$\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$", B, N); label("$\mathbf{p}$", P, N);
 [/asy] The vector $\mathbf{p}$ itself will be orthogonal to the direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix},$ so \[\begin{pmatrix} -5t + 4 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(-5t + 4)(-5) + (2t + 1)(2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{18}{29}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 26/29 \\ 65/29 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes v p :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "v = (26/29, 65/29)"
and h1 : "\<forall> u. (u = (4, 1) \<or> u = (-1, 3)) \<longrightarrow> p = (fst u * fst v + snd u * snd v) / (fst v * fst v + snd v * snd v) *\<^sub>R v"
shows  "p = (26/29, 65/29)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given a fixed vector $v = (\frac{26}{29}, \frac{65}{29})$, find the projection of vectors $u = (4, 1)$ and $u = (-1, 3)$ onto $v$. The final answer is $p = (\frac{26}{29}, \frac{65}{29})$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v :: "real*real" and p1 p2 :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "p1 = proj v (4,1)"
and h1 : "p2 = proj v (-1,3)"
shows  "p1 = p2" and "p1 = (26/29, 65/29)"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the vectors $\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 26/29 \\ 65/29 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Note that the vector $\mathbf{p}$ must lie on the line passing through $\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5t + 4 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); pair A, B, O, P; A = (4,1); B = (-1,3); O = (0,0); P = (O + reflect(A,B)*(O))/2; draw((-2,0)--(5,0)); draw((0,-1)--(0,4)); draw(O--A,Arrow(6)); draw(O--B,Arrow(6));
 draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(interp(A,B,-0.1)--interp(A,B,1.1),dashed); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$", A, N); label("$\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$", B, N); label("$\mathbf{p}$", P, N);
 [/asy] The vector $\mathbf{p}$ itself will be orthogonal to the direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix},$ so \[\begin{pmatrix} -5t + 4 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(-5t + 4)(-5) + (2t + 1)(2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{18}{29}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 26/29 \\ 65/29 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes v :: "real*real" and p1 p2 :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "p1 = proj v (4,1)"
and h1 : "p2 = proj v (-1,3)"
shows  "p1 = p2" and "p1 = (26/29, 65/29)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: If $p1$ and $p2$ are projections of vector $v$ onto $(4,1)$ and $(-1,3)$ respectively, find $p1$ and $p2$. Also show that $p1$ and $p2$ are equal and their value is $(26/29, 65/29)$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v p :: "real*real" and a b :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "a = (4, 1)"
and h1 : "b = (-1, 3)"
and h2 : "p = (\<lambda>x. (x \<bullet> v) / (v \<bullet> v) *\<^sub>R v) a"
and h3 : "p = (\<lambda>x. (x \<bullet> v) / (v \<bullet> v) *\<^sub>R v) b"
shows  "p = (26 / 29, 65 / 29)"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the vectors $\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 26/29 \\ 65/29 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Note that the vector $\mathbf{p}$ must lie on the line passing through $\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5t + 4 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); pair A, B, O, P; A = (4,1); B = (-1,3); O = (0,0); P = (O + reflect(A,B)*(O))/2; draw((-2,0)--(5,0)); draw((0,-1)--(0,4)); draw(O--A,Arrow(6)); draw(O--B,Arrow(6));
 draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(interp(A,B,-0.1)--interp(A,B,1.1),dashed); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$", A, N); label("$\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$", B, N); label("$\mathbf{p}$", P, N);
 [/asy] The vector $\mathbf{p}$ itself will be orthogonal to the direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix},$ so \[\begin{pmatrix} -5t + 4 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(-5t + 4)(-5) + (2t + 1)(2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{18}{29}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 26/29 \\ 65/29 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes v p :: "real*real" and a b :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "a = (4, 1)"
and h1 : "b = (-1, 3)"
and h2 : "p = (\<lambda>x. (x \<bullet> v) / (v \<bullet> v) *\<^sub>R v) a"
and h3 : "p = (\<lambda>x. (x \<bullet> v) / (v \<bullet> v) *\<^sub>R v) b"
shows  "p = (26 / 29, 65 / 29)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given the vectors $a = (4, 1)$ and $b = (-1, 3)$, find the projection $p$ of $a$ and $b$ onto a vector $v$. The final answer is $p = \left(\frac{26}{29}, \frac{65}{29}\right)$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v p :: "real*real" and u1 u2 :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "u1 = (4, 1)"
and h1 : "u2 = (-1, 3)"
and h2 : "p = (v \<bullet> u1 / (v \<bullet> v)) *\<^sub>R v"
and h3 : "p = (v \<bullet> u2 / (v \<bullet> v)) *\<^sub>R v"
shows  "p = (26 / 29, 65 / 29)"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the vectors $\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 26/29 \\ 65/29 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Note that the vector $\mathbf{p}$ must lie on the line passing through $\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5t + 4 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); pair A, B, O, P; A = (4,1); B = (-1,3); O = (0,0); P = (O + reflect(A,B)*(O))/2; draw((-2,0)--(5,0)); draw((0,-1)--(0,4)); draw(O--A,Arrow(6)); draw(O--B,Arrow(6));
 draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(interp(A,B,-0.1)--interp(A,B,1.1),dashed); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$", A, N); label("$\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$", B, N); label("$\mathbf{p}$", P, N);
 [/asy] The vector $\mathbf{p}$ itself will be orthogonal to the direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix},$ so \[\begin{pmatrix} -5t + 4 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(-5t + 4)(-5) + (2t + 1)(2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{18}{29}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 26/29 \\ 65/29 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes v p :: "real*real" and u1 u2 :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "u1 = (4, 1)"
and h1 : "u2 = (-1, 3)"
and h2 : "p = (v \<bullet> u1 / (v \<bullet> v)) *\<^sub>R v"
and h3 : "p = (v \<bullet> u2 / (v \<bullet> v)) *\<^sub>R v"
shows  "p = (26 / 29, 65 / 29)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem:
Find the vector $p$ that satisfies the following conditions:

- It is the projection of vectors $u1 = (4, 1)$ and $u2 = (-1, 3)$ onto vector $v$
- The dot product of $v$ and $u1$, divided by the dot product of $v$ with itself, times vector $v$ is equal to $p$
- The dot product of $v$ and $u2$, divided by the dot product of $v$ with itself, times vector $v$ is also equal to $p$

The final answer is $p = (\frac{26}{29}, \frac{65}{29})$.
